fr:title.text: Set is complete › construction of limits in Set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set is complete › construction of limits in Set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let J\xrightarrow {D} Set be a small diagram. We define \operatorname *{lim} D = \operatorname *{Cone}_D(*) = \operatorname {Hom}(*, D), where * is the constant functor at the singleton and \operatorname *{Cone} is the cone functor. Note that this is indeed a set, because J is small. An element of this set is a natural transformation *\xrightarrow {\mu } D, which consists of a morphism *\xrightarrow {\mu _j} Dj for each j\in J, hence canonically identifies a J-tuple of elements (x_i\in Dj). The legs of should be maps \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } Dj; we define these by (*\xrightarrow {\mu } D)\xmapsto {\lambda _j} \mu _j(*).

To show that this cone is limiting, let Z\xrightarrow {
u } D be a cone. We need to show that 
u factors uniquely through \lambda . An element z\in Z identifies a map *	o Z, and hence a cone *	o Z\xrightarrow {
u } D, which is thus an element t(z)\in \operatorname *{lim} D. Now \lambda _j(t(z)) = (
u z)_j = 
u _j(z), and so 
u = \lambda t, as desired. It remains to show uniqueness, but any function Z\xrightarrow {u} \operatorname *{lim} D factoring 
u must satisfy u(z)_j = \lambda _j(u(z)) = 
u _j(z) = (
u z)_j = t(z)_j, so we are done.
Set is complete.

By the completeness criterion, it suffices to give products and equalizers. Products are given by the cartesian product. The equalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows }B is \{a\in A: f(a) = b(a)\}.

Let J\xrightarrow {D} Set be a small diagram. We define \operatorname *{lim} D = \operatorname *{Cone}_D(*) = \operatorname {Hom}(*, D), where * is the constant functor at the singleton and \operatorname *{Cone} is the cone functor. Note that this is indeed a set, because J is small. An element of this set is a natural transformation *\xrightarrow {\mu } D, which consists of a morphism *\xrightarrow {\mu _j} Dj for each j\in J, hence canonically identifies a J-tuple of elements (x_i\in Dj). The legs of should be maps \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } Dj; we define these by (*\xrightarrow {\mu } D)\xmapsto {\lambda _j} \mu _j(*).

To show that this cone is limiting, let Z\xrightarrow {
u } D be a cone. We need to show that 
u factors uniquely through \lambda . An element z\in Z identifies a map *	o Z, and hence a cone *	o Z\xrightarrow {
u } D, which is thus an element t(z)\in \operatorname *{lim} D. Now \lambda _j(t(z)) = (
u z)_j = 
u _j(z), and so 
u = \lambda t, as desired. It remains to show uniqueness, but any function Z\xrightarrow {u} \operatorname *{lim} D factoring 
u must satisfy u(z)_j = \lambda _j(u(z)) = 
u _j(z) = (
u z)_j = t(z)_j, so we are done.
Grp is regular.

Let \hat {C} be a presheaf category. Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {\Omega } Set be the sieve functor, which sends an object x to the set of sieves on x, and a map y\xrightarrow {f}x to its action on sieves by restriction: (\Omega f)(S) = \{g: fg\in S\}. Let *\xhookrightarrow {\top } \Omega (where * is the constant functor at the singleton) identify for each x\in C the maximal sieve. Then \top is a subobject classifier in \hat {C}.

Let Q\hookrightarrow P be a subobject in \hat {C}. We need to define the classifying natural transformation P\xrightarrow {\chi _Q}\Omega ; we work in components. At an object x\in C, this map must send an element p\in Px to a sieve on x; we choose the sieve (\chi _Q)_x(p) = \{z\xrightarrow {f} x\in C: p|_f \in Qz\}. In other words, this sieve consists of those maps which restrict p to an element of Q.

Next, to show that it is a pullback, it suffices to show that it is a pullback at each x\in C, and by the construction of limits in Set, it suffices to show that (\chi _Q)_x(p) is the maximal sieve if and only if p\in Qx. The backwards direction is already done; conversely, if it is the maximal sieve, then we obtain the result by observing that 1_x\in (\chi _Q)_x(p) and applying the definition of \chi _Q.

Finally, to show uniqueness, suppose that we have another natural transformation P\xrightarrow {\theta } \Omega . By the above argument, for the square to be a pullback, we must have that \theta _x(p) is the maximal sieve if and only if p\in Qx. Now further, given z\xrightarrow {f} x and applying the same fact at z, we must have that p|_f\in Qz if and only if \theta _z(p|_f) is the maximal sieve. By naturality of \theta at a map f, we have that \theta _z(p|_f) = \Omega f(\theta _x(p)), which by definition of \Omega is the maximal sieve if and only if f\in \theta _x(p). As a consequence, if the square is a pullback, we must have that f\in \theta _x(p) if and only if p|_f\in Qz, yielding exactly the definition of \chi _Q above.

Let I\times J\xrightarrow {F} C be a bifunctorial diagram such that the limits \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J F and \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I F exist. Then \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} F exists, and the three limits are isomorphic.

Since representable isomorphism implies isomorphism, it suffices to prove that C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J F) \cong C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} F) \cong C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I F) naturally in X. Since hom functors preserve limits, the desired result becomes \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J C(X, F) \cong \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} C(X, F) \cong \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I C(X, F); i.e., the general case reduces to that of Set. By the isomorphism I\times J\cong J\times I, it suffices to prove the first isomorphism.

The proof is essentially by currying. Let I\times J\xrightarrow {G} Set be a diagram. By the construction of limits in Set, the limit \operatorname *{lim}_J G(i, -) is the set of cones over G(i, -) with summit *, hence equivalently the set of J-tuples (x_j\in G(i, j)) satisfying G(i, f)(x_j) = x_{j'} for each j\xrightarrow {f}j'\in J. Taking the limit over I, we now conclude that \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J G consists of the tuples (x_{ij}\in G(i, j)) which commute with G-images of maps in I and J. This is exactly the data of \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} G.

Let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a diagram in a locally small category C whose limit exists. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(x, \operatorname *{lim} F)\cong \operatorname *{lim} C(x, F-), where the latter is a limit in Set.
Dually, let the colimit of F exist. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} F, x)\cong \operatorname *{lim}_{J^\text {op}} C(F-, x).
The singleton set * is the terminal object in Set. Explicitly, it is the set with one element.

A cone over a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C with apex c\in C is a natural transformation c\xrightarrow {\lambda } D, where c is the constant functor at c. Explicitly, a cone consists of, for each object j\in J, a morphism c\xrightarrow {\lambda _j} Dj, so that for each morphism j\xrightarrow {f}k\in J, the following diagram commutes:
The components \lambda _j of the cone are called its legs.

Let c be an object in a category C, and let J be any category. The constant functor at c is the functor J\xrightarrow {c} C that sends every object of J to c and every morphism of J to the identity 1_c.

The constant functors induce a functor C\xrightarrow {\Delta } J^C to the functor category which sends each object of C to the corresponding constant functor and each morphism x\xrightarrow {f}y to the natural transformation with components \alpha _j = f for each j\in J.
A commutatitive diagram in a category C is a functor J\xrightarrow {D} C. The domain J is called the indexing category or the shape of the diagram.
A limit of a diagram is a universal cone.

By the definition of universal elements, a limit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{lim} D\in C and a cone \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(-, \operatorname *{lim} D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D.
A category is small if its collection of morphisms forms a set.
